title: 107_hr4767
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Act to Prioritize Spending" and includes amendments to sections 251 and 275. The Congressional Act to Prioritize Spending includes amendments to sections 251 and 275 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The amendments involve adjustments to discretionary spending limits and the redesignation of paragraphs related to fiscal years 2002 and 2003. The new budget authority for the discretionary category is set at $746,174,000,000. The Congressional Act to Prioritize Spending includes amendments to sections 251 and 275 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The amendments involve adjustments to discretionary spending limits and the redesignation of paragraphs related to fiscal years 2002 and 2003. The new budget authority for the discretionary category is set at $746,174,000,000, with a significant portion allocated to defense. The Congressional Act to Prioritize Spending includes adjustments to discretionary spending limits for fiscal year 2005. The new budget authority for the discretionary category is $804,455,000,000, with a significant portion allocated to defense. In fiscal year 2006, the discretionary category will have $831,378,000,000 in new budget authority, with $442,515,000,000 allocated for defense. For fiscal year 2007, the discretionary category will have $864,998,000,000 in new budget authority, with $464,415,000,000 allocated for defense. For fiscal year 2007, the discretionary category will have $864,998,000,000 in new budget authority, with not less than $464,415,000,000 for defense. Adjustments to discretionary spending limits include provisions for new budget authority for the Department of Defense to prosecute the war on terrorism. Adjustments to discretionary spending limits include provisions for new budget authority for the Department of Defense to prosecute the war on terrorism, totaling $10,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2003. An adjustment cannot be made if the funds are designated as an emergency requirement. The resolution provides over $7.5 billion in new budget authority for grants to States under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act for fiscal year 2003. If a bill is enacted with over $9.5 billion for fiscal year 2004, the adjustment will be $1.75 billion in new budget authority. The bill provides $10,755,000,000 in new budget authority for grants to States under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act for fiscal year 2005. If a bill is enacted with $12,047,000,000 for fiscal year 2006, the adjustment will be $3,894,000,000 in new budget authority. If a bill provides at least $13,497,000,000 in new budget authority for grants to States under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act for fiscal year 2007, the adjustment will be $5,180,000,000 in new budget authority. Additionally, if a bill is enacted that charges Federal agencies for the full cost of accrued Federal retirement and health benefits, and provides new budget authority for this purpose, adjustments will be made accordingly. If a bill amends the Higher Education Act to make student aid administration subject to annual appropriations, adjustments will be made for fiscal years 2003 and 2004 totaling $797,000,000 and $813,000,000 respectively in new budget authority and outlays. For fiscal years 2004 to 2007, additional new budget authority and outlays totaling $813,000,000 to $871,000,000 were allocated. The limitation for fiscal year 2003 for highway programs is $23,864,000,000 with an adjustment not to exceed $1,180,000,000 in outlays. An adjustment can only be made if the obligation limitation is solely for programs under the Transportation Equity Act. Section 275(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 expires in 2007.
